	  * of subsequent lines, then use stripMargin to remove the surplus indentation.

data.description:
Simple: Infix Operators are available if an object
  has a method that takes one parameter.
data.code:
val g: Int = 3
(g + 4) should be(__) // + is an infix operator
 g.+(4) should be(__) // same result but not using the infix operator

data.description:
Infix Operators do NOT work if an object
  has a method that takes two parameters.
data.code:
val g: String = "Check out the big brains on Brad!"
g indexOf 'o' should be(__) can be used as an infix operator
//g indexOf 'o', 4 should be (__) cannot be used an infix operator
g.indexOf('o', 7) should be(__) must use standard java/scala calls

data.description:
Postfix operators work if an object
  has a method that takes no parameters.

Prefix operators work if an object
  has a method name that starts with unary_ .
data.code:
val g: Int = 31
(-g) should be(__)

data.description:
Here we create our own prefix operator for our own class.
   The only identifiers that can be used as prefix operators
   are +, -, !, and ~
data.code:
class Stereo {
  def unary_+ = "on"

  def unary_- = "off"
}

val stereo = new Stereo
(+stereo) should be(__)
(-stereo) should be(__)

data.description: Lists have many useful methods
Functions over lists can use _ as shorthand
data.code:

a.map { _ * 2 } should equal(__)

data.description: Functions over lists can use () instead of {}

data.description: Lists can be 'reduced' with a mathematical operation
